rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The reticular formation and generalized seizures
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The object of this investigation was to gain insight, by experimental means, into the presumed role of the reticular core in the mechanisms of generalized seizures. Denis Williams, in his recent review article, The Thalamus and Epilepsy (1965), has posed the question in a somewhat different form: "Is the intact centrencephalon essential for the propagation of seizures?" It is not realistic to consider the reticular formation either functionally or structurally in isolation. Its extent, events and effects are by very definition widespread and diffuse. Current concepts of epileptic pathway propagation unfortunately lack precision.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Neurology and Neurosurgery

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Glycolysis in rat muscle homogenates
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The study of glycolysis is a broad and extensive subject. The amount of published data dealing with glycolysis in different tissues and systems, as well as referring to special aspects of the process, are abundant and most of them of great interest. The accumulation of knowledge on the subject is of such magnitude that it is difficult for any single individual to read and summarize all that is published about it. In the present work, the writer will deal only with the aspects of glycolysis in muscle, limiting the references to those investigations which in some manner are linked to the work presented in this thesis.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Biochemistry

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Formation of plasma clotting factor VII by Vitamin K1 in a cell free system
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Liver homogenates (33% w/v) from vitamin K-deficient rats incubated in a bicarbonate buffer form plasma clotting factor VII in the presence of vitamin K1. After centrifugation, the activity is found in the postmitochondrial supernatant (30 x 10^3 g supernatant). Neither the postmicrosomal supernatant (100 x 10^3 g supernatant) nor the microsomal pellet (100 x 10^3 g pellet) alone has activity, but if the two are recombined a response to vitamin K1 is obtained. Liver homogenates and their subcellular fractions from warfarin pretreated rats fail to produce factor VII in the presence of vitamin K1. To localize the intracellular site of inhibition by warfarin, "cross-mixing" experiments were performed. When the postmicrosomal supernatant from warfarin pretreated rats was mixed with the microsomal pellet from vitamin K-deficient rats a response to vitamin K1 was obtained, whereas the recombination of the postmicrosomal supernatant from vitamin K-deficient rats with the microsomal pellet from warfarin pretreated rats gave no response. The results show that the formation of plasma clotting factor VII by vitamin K1 can be produced in a cell free system and that the intracellular site of inhibition by warfarin is in the microsomal fraction.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Pharmacology

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Studies on blood ethandl concentration in human subjects
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Although ethanol absorption has been studied extensively for over 100 years, many questions remain unanswered regarding the individual variation range of absorption and factors affecting it. In the present study, ethanol absorption was investigated in 60 human subjects in an attempt to establish the factors affecting the normal variation range. In all cases, a standard dose of ethanol was administered in a fasting state and their blood ethanol concentrations were studied. The time period taken for the maximum blood ethanol concentration to be achieved reflects gastric absorption. By studying the timing of this maximum, the subjects could be divided into 3 groups; rapid, standard and delayed absorbers. The effects of milk, olive oil and glucuronolactone an ethanol absorption were investigated. Milk and olive oil decreased the overall blood ethanol concentration in the majority of subjects, while glucuronolactone had variable effect.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Experimental Medicine

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Properties of somato-sympathetic reflexes
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The reflex behaviour of single sympathetic preganglionic neurons in response to supramaximal stimulation of the sciatic nerve was studied with extracellular microelectrodes in anaesthetized cats. In 36% of the units single shocks evoked single spike discharges with mean latencies ranging from 50 to 300 msec. In 16% of the units single shocks evoked a depression of background activity with latencies ranging from 60 to 300 msec and lasting 700 msec on the average. With repetitive stimulation over a wide range of stimulation frequencies the maximum excitatory or inhibitory effect was obtained in individual units at frequencies below 10 cps. A unit was either excited or inhibited, but not both, over the whole range of stimulus frequencies used. The known phenomenon of reversal of blood pressure reflex response (from depressor to pressor) with increasing frequency of somatic afferent stimulation can be explained on the basis of some of these findings.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Physiology

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Regional capillary blood flow and oxygen update in severe sepsis
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Measurements were made of cardiac output, blood flow in skeletal muscle, oxygen uptake, and femoral and total arteriovenous oxygen differences, before and after induction of a septic lesion in dogs. Half of the animals developed a hyperdynamic circulation in response to sepsis, and the rise in cardiac output was significantly correlated with an increase in muscle capillary blood flow, demonstrating that no pre-capillary arteriovenous shunts were present. The increased flow was also related to decreased arteriovenous oxygen extraction. It was also demonstrated that after muscle exercise, in contrast to the findings after sepsis, the arteriovenous oxygen extraction was increased. This study suggests that the sequence of events seen in hypovolemic or cardiac shock (where low tissue perfusion and tissue hypoxia cause secondary cellular damage) is reversed in septic shock; a primary cellular defect occurs, causing the hemodynamic disturbance as an attempted compensatory mechanism.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Experimental Surgery

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Properties of biological perfusates for extracorporeal support of the isolated heart
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The experiments included in this work were carried out for the purpose of studying some of the properties of blood and plasma and their effects on the preservation of left ventricular contractility during hypothermic coronary perfusion of the isolated heart. When blood is used to support the heart, both its viscosity and diffusible calcium concentration play an important role in determining the level of left ventricular function. The existence of a linear relationship between the viscosity of blood and left ventricular pressure has been demonstrated. Various compounds capable of raising the viscosity of plasma have been evaluated. Hydroxyethyl starch (HES) is the most suitable because of its stability and lack of toxicity. When the viscosity of plasma is progressively raised, a calcium dependent linear relationship between perfusate viscosity and left ventricular pressure was also obtained. Although the properties of blood, resulting from its high viscosity cannot entirely be duplicated by artificially raising the viscosity of plasma, a new equilibrium can be achieved which although different from that of blood produces the same effects.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Experimental Surgery

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Development of a bioassay for the determination of ACTH
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: This assay was based on the corticosterone response to the intravenous administration of ACTH in 4 hours hypophysectomized rats. The corticosterone from peripheral blood was measured by a method based on the competitive binding of corticosteroids to Corticosteroid Binding Globulin. The Second and Third International Standard ACTH have been compared and the ACTH potency of synthetic analogs and of different species measured. This assay has been applied to the measurement of ACTH from various tumors and metastases with ectopic ACTH syndrome. A very good correlation has been achieved between the data presented in our results and those of others. The chief contribution of this assay is its application of the competitive protein binding method which requires only 10 µl of rat plasma for routine determination of corticosterone.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Experimental Medicine

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Studies on the pathogenesis of the ophthalmopathy of Graves’ disease
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Two daily injections of lU TSH increased 35S-sulfate uptake by the guinea pig harderian gland (J. Lab. Clin. Med. 61:44, 1963). We studied the 35S-sulfate uptake in the mouse to find a more suitable sensitive animal. Female Allimo mice 15-18 gm, were fed low iodine diet containing thyroid USP for 4 days; 40 UC 35S-sulfate was injected ip with TSH or 0.5 ml twofold concentrate serum gamma-globulin. The harderian gland was removed and disso1ved in hyamine hydroxide and its radioactivity determined. A single injection of 10 mu TSH enhanced 6 hr 35S-sulfate uptake and no further augumentation was observed with higher doses of TSH.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Experimental Medicine

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Microbial degradation of agar enzymatic hydrolysis of neoagarotetraose
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The purified extracellular agarases produced by marine microorganisms hydrolyze the 8-1, 4 galactosidic linkages of agarose to yield a homologous series of neoagarosaccharides. A predominant end product after complete enzymic hydrolysis of agarose is the tetrasaccharide, neoagarotetraose, which is resistant to further degradation by agarase. This project involved the isolation of a 8-tetrasaccharidase from Pseudomonas atlantica, which hydrolyzes the 8-1, 4 linkage of neoagarotetraose. The cell-bound β-tetrasaccharidase, selectively released by EDTA-Tris-NaCl treatment of P. atlantica cells, was free of α-disaccharidase activity. β-Tetrasaccharidase and agarase were separated by isoelectric focusing and were shown to possess distinct pl values. Determination of the isoelectric points facilitated separation of the enzymes on DEAE-Sephadex. Specificity studies were carried out on the crude and DEAE-purified β-tetrasaccharidase preparations. The possible location of the β-tetrasaccharidase in the cell and some of the enzyme characteristics are discussed.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Microbiology and Immunology

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Isolation of cationic glycoprotein allergens from short ragweed pollen
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: A cationic glycoprotein allergen, antigen Ra.3, was isolated from short ragweed pollen by gel filtration and anion exchange chromatography according to a previously published procedure. It had an amino acid composition in close agreement with published data, except for an appreciably lower proline and isoleucine content. The method of isolation was modified to incorporate cation exchange chromatography for more rapid and reproducible isolation of the allergen in amounts of 100 mg/kg pollen. The isolated product was examined for homogeneity by physicochemical and immunological techniques, and some of its physical and chemical properties were determined. Three other cationic, allergenically active, carbohydrate-containing components were isolated which gave reactions of identity on immunodiffusion with rabbit antiserum to antigen Ra.3. Some preliminary chemical properties of the cross-reacting components were determined.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Biochemistry

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Some studies of carbohydrate metabolism in rat skeletal muscle
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The factors controlling the rate of glycolysis in rat skeletal muscle homogenates and extracts were studied. Hexokinase was identified as the first rate-limiting step. In slightly acidic muscle extracts, the phospho- , fructokinase step was limiting. This was related to the amount of soluble and insoluble forms of the enzyme. The relative amounts of each form depended on the pH. The rate-limiting effect was shown to be eliminated when the muscle extracts were prepared in a slightly alkaline medium. The importance of the ATPase in the homogenates and extracts in controlling the rate of glycolysis was also shown. Increasing the amount of ATPase up to a certain level stimulates glycolysis by supplying ADP for the phosphoglycerate kinase and pyruvate kinase steps. Various enzymatic and colorimetric methods for the assay of intermediates of the pentose phosphate pathway were studied. Transaldolase was partially purified from Candida utilis.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Biochemistry

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Preparation, preservation and electron transport system of mung bean mitochondria
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: A procedure for isolating mitochondrial particles with relatively high respiratory activity and good respiratory control in quantity from etiolated Mung bean (Phaseolus aureus) seedlings is described. The mitochondrial preparation can be preserved in the frozen state for two to four weeks by freezing at -15°C in the presence of dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) and bovine serum albumin (BSA). Damage to mitochondria by freezing at 77°K may be reduced by DMSO addition. The supplements Ficoll, dextran, MgCl2, KCl, dithiothreitol (DTT) and DMSO had no importance as stabllizers of the activity of mitochondria in liquid suspension (0°c), whereas Tricine (N-Tris (hydroxymethyl) methylglycine) and BSA, both, significantly stabilized succinate oxidase activity and Tricine also slowed the decline of respiratory control by ADP. From the polarographic and spectrophotometric studies, using respiratory inhibitors and donors, a scheme of the basic electron transport chain in Mung bean mitochondria is proposed.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Biochemistry

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Les troubles de voisinnage en matière aeronautique
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Cette thèse étudie le bruit aux environs des aéroports américains et français; aussi commence-t-elle à lui donner une identité en le définissant par rapport aux autres formes qu'il est susceptible de prendre et en exposant ses éffets sur les biens et les personnes. Le plan est axe autour d'une démonstration en trois parties: thèse, anti-thèse, synthèse. La première partie traite de la répréssion des troubles de voisinage au nom des intérêts privés représentés par les propriétaires lésés; elle met en lumière la menace qui pèse sur les compagnies aeriennes.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Air and Space Law

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Effects of seeding dates and population density on the survival and yield of summer and winter forms of rapeseed
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Experiments were conducted at Macdonald College to determine the feasibility of growing winter and summer forms of rapeseed. Two seasons of experimentation with the summer form and one with the winter form indicated that these could be grown successfully. Date of seeding was determined to be a critical factor affecting, yield, particularly with the summer form. It was suggested that the summer form should be seeded as early as possible in the spring and the winter form during the latter part of August. Population density did not have a major effect on the seed yield of either the summer or the winter form. Nitrogen level affected the yield of the summer form. Vernalization of the winter form took place mainly during the month of November, while winterkilling did not occur until March.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Agronomy

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The morphology and vascular relationships of the human ductus venosus in the early postnatal period
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The ductus venosus and associated vessels of sixty-six livers taken at autopsy from subjects ranging from stillborn to 60 years of age were examined by dissection and histological serial sections or by means of vascular casts. The ductal inlet was in line with the umbilical vein outlet (48.2%) or displaced to its right (1 - 8 mm.). The duct terminated in the left hepatic vein (48.4%), the inferior vena cava (25.8%) or the confluence of the left and middle hepatic veins (25.8%). Anatomical patency persisted in the forty-five specimens aged 0 - 7 days. A non-sphincteric lip was observed at the narrowed ductal inlet. After 7 days the duct was closed in most specimens at least at the portal end. Closure proceeded, by subendothelial thickenings, from portal to caval end. The ductal wall had abundant collagen, extensive elastic networks and a moderate muscular component. The ductal elongation rate was greatly reduced postnatally.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Anatomy

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Dichotic listening in hearing-impaired children
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Ear asymmetry for dichotic digits was used to indicate speech laterality in 19 hearing-impaired and 19 normal-hearing children. Sequences of 2, 4 and 6 digits were also presented monaurally. Whereas for the normal-hearing group right-ear dichotic scores were significantly superior, inter-subject variability resulted in a non-significant right-ear trend for the hearing-impaired group, with individuals showing marked right or left-ear advantage. The groups did not differ significantly in relative right-left hand proficiency. No correlation was found between hand and ear laterality in either group, nor between degree of ear asymmetry and vocabulary scores for hearing-impaired subjects. Discrimination of a dichotic pair by the latter subjects rarely occurred, with one digit apparently masking or suppressing the other. Prediction of speech lateralization in hearing-impaired children from dichotic digit scores was not recommended.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Human Communications Disorders

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Cardiopulmonary studies in critical illness: changes in aspiration pneumonitis
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Cardiopulmonary studies in eighteen patients with aspiration pneumonitis and thirteen patients with shock or sepsis have been correlated with routine laboratory, X-ray and pathologic findings. The hypoxaemia and widened A-aDO2 observed in aspiration pneumonitis improved with IPPV, suggesting maldistribution of ventilation compatible with pulmonary oedema. Progressive plasma volume loss averaging 500 ml. after 24 hours was associated with hypotension and was best corrected by careful replacement with colloid solutions. Cardiac failure only occured in patients with pre-existing heart disease or overtransfusion. The pneumonitis was initially non-infective; and antibiotics did not prevent subsequent pulmonary infection. The mortality was 40 percent in aspiration pneumonitis and 70 percent in shock and sepsis. Advanced age, pH of aspirated gastric contents below 1.75, prolonged hypoxia and concurrent sepsis were the main factors associated with high mortality.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Experimental Surgery

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Alteration of mortality rate and gasto-intestinal lesions in severely burned rats fed an elemental diet
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Experimental gastro-intestinal lesions secondary to extensive surface burns have studied in rats and thought to be similar to the lesions observed in hemorrhagic shock. Because of the beneficial effect reported from pre-feeding a shocked animal an elemental diet, we served this preparation to our burnt animals. The elemental diet is a liquid diet equivalent to the normal diet, but in which total protein has been replaced by amino acids. We observed a significant improvement of the 24 hour mortality rate and a marked reduction in the incidence of the gastrointestinal lesions. It is impossible to feed the elemental diet to a patient prior to burn, but because the gastrointestinal lesions secondary to burns encountered clinically are delayed, we believe that the elemental diet could find some application in extensive burn therapy.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Experimental Surgery

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Histological and histochemical studies on pathological states of the ureter (in particular congenital ureteropelvic junction obstruction and ‘adynamic’ distal ureteral segments)
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The histology and histochemistry in clinical and experimental hydronephrosis due to pelviureteric strictures and adynamic ureters have been studied. It has been shown that in a certain number of congenital ureteropelvic junction stenosis and adynamic distal ureters there is an abnormality in the muscle pattern. Histochemical studies have demonstrated the presence of both cholergic and adrenergic components in the dilated ureter but have not been useful thus far in assessment of quantitative changes.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Experimental Surgery

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Urinary excretion of some corticosteroid 21-YL sulfates during human pregnancy
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Several steroids of the pregn-4-ene-21-yl sulfate series were previously quantified in the urine of newborn infants, and their daily output found to represent a very significant proportion of that of tetrahydrocortisone glucuronide. To determine the possible origin of these conjugates, their excretion was measured in women prior to and following parturition and in non-pregnant women. Double isotope assays were employed to characterize and quantify all urinary steroids, the main ones being the sulfates of cortisol, cortisone, corticosterone, 11-dehydrocorticosterone, and the glucuronides of tetrahydrocortisone and tetrahydrocortisol. Prior to delivery the mean excretion of cortisol sulfate and cortisone sulfate was 193 and 54 µg /day. The values for the glucuronides of tetrahydrocortisol and tetrahydrocortisone were 986 and 2000 µg/day. The mean excretion rate of corticosterone sulfate and 11-dehydrocorticosterone sulfate was 219 and 35 µg/day respectively. Following parturition the excretion of all these sulfates decreased three to sevenfold, falling within the range observed for non-pregnant women. The data are consistent with our previous hypothesis that during the last trimester of pregnancy these steroid sulfates originate mainly from the fetus. Following birth their urinary output by the newborn reflects processes which were initiated in utero.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Experimental Medicine

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Composition of alginate in relation to strontium binding
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Alginic acid from Laminaria hyperborea was partially hydrolysed and the non-dialysable degradation products were fractionated into several components, with different proportions of guluronic and mannuronic acid. Sodium salts of these products were examined by intubation technique in rats for their suppressive activity of intestinal absorption of radioactive strontium and calcium. In vitro binding capacity was tested by dialysis against water containing strontium and calcium. 'Poly-L-guluronic acid' was found to be most effective; its degradation products did not show any higher activity. These degradation products had a lower degree of polymerization than the parent compound and it appears that the maximal gel formation with strontium occurs. It was concluded that high biological activity is dependent on chemical composition, including guluronic acid content, viscosity, chain length. Inhibition of calcium absorption was invariably low and the various preparations did not show any significant difference in their effectiveness.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Experimental Medicine

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The effects of hepatectomy on body spaces in the dog
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The role of the liver in the control of body water was evaluated by performing body space measurements before and after total hepatectomy in the doge Standard isotopic dilutional techniques were carried out, using tritium for Total Body Water; Na22 and Inulin for Extracellular Water; Cr51 for Red Cell Volume and I121 for plasma volume and Glomerular Filtration Rate. The only significant changes observed were for the PV and RCV and these changes can probably be accounted for by pre, intra and post-operative blood loss. The stable extracellular spaces were parallelled by unchanging large vessel and whole body hematocrits. Although not statistically significant, some interesting tendencies were observed when the sodium and inulin spaces were compared, suggesting that the simultaneous use of a large non-diffusable molecule and a smaller diffusable isotope could be beneficial in estimating the interstitial water space.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Experimental Medicine

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The role of adenosine triphosphate in the phosphorylation of membrane components of chromaffin granules
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Adenosine triphosphate acts on the ATPase of chromaffin granules of the adrenal medulla to release catecholamines, endogenous ATP, and soluble protein (Poisner and Trifaró, Mol. Pharmacol., 3: 572, 1967). In the present study, chromaffin granules were isolated by means of a new technique that consisted of an isotonic density gradient, which yielded a relatively pure fraction of granules suitable for in vitro studies. The distribution of the different subcellular organelles in the gradient was determined by different enzyme markers.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Pharmacology and Therapeutics

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Plasma progesterone levels in human pregnancy. A study by competitive protein binding
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Plasma progesterone levels in normal and abnormal human pregnancy have been determined by Competitive protein Binding, utilizing the affinity of progesterone for corticosteroid binding globulin. The technique is rapid (8 hours), sensitive (to 1 microgram/100 ml.), and requires small sample volumes (1 ml.). The sensitivity, specificity, accuracy and precision of the assay have been determined. The literature on progesterone in pregnancy has been reviewed concerning; synthesis and metabolism, reported plasma levels and alternative assay techniques. Plasma progesterone levels, (in microgram/100 ml.), are reported throughout normal pregnancy to delivery, (early: 1 - 5, late; 5 - 25), postpartum (0), and fetal levels (umbilical vein; 40.8, artery; 18.7). There is poor correlation between progesterone levels and the "progesterone effect" by vaginal cytology. In threatened abortion, abnormally low progesterone levels (below 1), carry a poor prognosis. With intrauterine fetal death, levels varied from abnormally low to normal values, (1.1 - 15.8).
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Experimental Medicine
